prop.head.headtext: Handling Cases Before the Judicial Panel on Multidistrict Litigation

head.headtext: Selection of a transferee judge generally

para.paratext: The next decision to be made by the Panel once it determines that transfer is appropriate is to select a particular judge to preside over the coordinated or consolidated pretrial proceedings. To some degree the selection of the judge may be the compelling factor in deciding the question of what district is appropriate,[1] in others is it clearly a separate question, taken up after the questions of transfer and appropriate district have been decided. The assigned judge may be a judge regularly assigned to the transferee court or may be a judge specially assigned from another district.

This decision is only reached if the Panel decides to order transfer. As is indicated in Chapters 5 and 6, however, the decision to transfer and the selection of a transferee district may depend in part upon the availability of a judge who is suited to handle the pretrial proceedings in the litigation. The factors are separate, but their overlap is discussed in this chapter.
Maslon Edelman Borman & Brand, LLP, Minneapolis, Minnesota.
See, e.g., In re Silica Products Liability Litigation, 280 F. Supp. 2d 1381 (J.P.M.L. 2003).
